successfulResults.originalText: Forgotten Star Dorothy Stratten Almost Lived the Hollywood Fairy Tale. It Ended as a Horror Story....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy Stratten was a famous actress.

She almost lived a happy life in Hollywood.

But her life ended in a sad way....

successfulResults.originalText: Peter Bogdanovich, Bob Fosse, and Hugh Hefner all loved her, in their own ways—for better and worse. This reexamination of Stratten’s life, rape, and murder casts a new light on the angel who was a ce...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Peter Bogdanovich, Bob Fosse, and Hugh Hefner liked her.

* They liked her in different ways.
* Some liked her for good reasons.
* Some liked her for bad reasons.

This story looks at her life again.
...

successfulResults.originalText: PICTURE PERFECT Dorothy Stratten was still in high school when she entered the Great Playmate Hunt....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy Stratten was a high school student.

* She entered a contest called the Great Playmate Hunt.
* This contest was for a magazine called Playboy....

successfulResults.originalText: Steve Schapiro/Getty Images....
successfulResults.simplifiedText: Steve Schapiro is a photographer....

successfulResults.originalText: Before it was a horror story, it was a fairy tale....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
It was once a happy story.

But it was not happy.
It was scary.
It was a horror story.

Now it is a happy story again.
It is a fairy tale....

successfulResults.originalText: Once upon a time (in 1978) in a Podunk town (Coquitlam, on the outskirts of Vancouver) lived a young girl named Dorothy Hoogstraten. Dorothy, 17, a high school senior, was working her usual shift at a...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
In 1978, a girl named Dorothy lived in a town called Coquitlam.

* She was 17 years old.
* She was a high school student.
* She worked at a Dairy Queen.

One day, a man named Paul Snider came in. 

* ...

successfulResults.originalText: Snider didn’t tell Dorothy he was a pimp; told Dorothy he was a promoter, which he also was. In LA, he’d put on the California Truckin’ & Cycle Show at the Convention Center. Photographer Howard Koby ...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you read this story:

* Meet Snider, a man with many jobs.
* He told people he was a promoter, which is true.
* He put on a big car show in LA.

A photographer named Howard met Snider in a specia...

successfulResults.originalText: Snider wooed Dorothy: bought her flowers, sang to her, took her to prom. He was always trying to get her clothes off. So he could have sex with her, naturally; but really so he could photograph her. P...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy's boyfriend, Snider, tried to get her to do things she didn't want to do.

* He gave her flowers and sang to her.
* He took her to the prom.

But Snider wanted more. He wanted to take pictures...

successfulResults.originalText: If Dorothy was ambivalent about the camera, the camera was not ambivalent about Dorothy. It was gaga for her. In her test shots, she conveyed a mixture of innocence and eroticism; purity but with inti...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy was not sure about the camera. But the camera loved her.

* The camera took pictures of Dorothy.
* She looked very innocent in the pictures.
* But there was something that made you want to kno...

successfulResults.originalText: Snider worked hard to persuade her mother, Nelly (her father, Simon, had long been out of the picture), to sign a release. When he failed, he signed it for Nelly—a forgery—sent it to Playboy. Hugh Hef...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Snider tried to get his mom to sign a paper.

* He wanted her to sign it so he could send it to Playboy.
* But she wouldn't sign it.

Snider signed the paper for his mom anyway.
He sent it to Playboy....

successfulResults.originalText: Though Dorothy wasn’t the winner of the contest, she was the runner-up. And Snider saw to it that her star only rose from there. A recollection of Louise’s: “We were watching The Sonny & Cher Show at ...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy was not the winner of the contest. 
She was the second best. 

Paul Snider helped her become famous. 
He controlled many things in her life. 

Her name was changed to Stratten. 
Paul liked the...

successfulResults.originalText: Snider’s methods were dubious; his results were not. In short succession, Dorothy landed Playmate of the Month (August 1979); a lead role in the BDSM thriller Autumn Born (she played a spoiled-rotten ...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy's methods were not good. But her results were great.

She did many things:

* She was Playmate of the Month in August 1979.
* She was in a movie called Autumn Born. 
  - She played a rich girl...

successfulResults.originalText: In March 1980, Dorothy, now 20, headed to New York to begin filming with Peter Bogdanovich, 40. She’d met the celebrated director at the Playboy Mansion. He was immediately struck by her refinement, h...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy went to New York in March 1980.

* She was 20 years old.
* She was working with a famous director named Peter Bogdanovich.
* He was 40 years old.

Dorothy met Peter at a big house called the P...

successfulResults.simplifiedText:

* She was really staying with Bogdanovich at another hotel.
* Bogdanovich didn't want to be bothered.

successfulResults.originalText: One of the few grace notes in Dorothy’s story, and the only apology Hollywood ever gave her....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
